entries.meaning: Last made; hence, made of refuse; inferior.
examples: We know your thoughts of us, that laymen are lag souls, and rubbish of remaining clay.

entries.meaning: (countable) A gap, a delay; an interval created by something not keeping up; a latency.
examples: During the Second World War, for instance, the Washington Senators had a starting rotation that included four knuckleball pitchers. But, still, I think that some of that was just a generational lag.
When the lag is low, 2 or 3 seconds perhaps, Internet chatters seem reasonably content.

entries.meaning: (Britain, slang, archaic) One sentenced to transportation for a crime.

examples: On both these occasions I had ended up behind the bars, and you might suppose that an old lag like myself would have been getting used to it by now.

entries.meaning: (snooker) A method of deciding which player shall start. Both players simultaneously strike a cue ball from the baulk line to hit the top cushion and rebound down the table; the player whose ball finishes closest to the baulk cushion wins.
One who lags; that which comes in last.
The fag-end; the rump; hence, the lowest class.

A stave of a cask, drum, etc.; especially (engineering) one of the narrow boards or staves forming the covering of a cylindrical object, such as a boiler, or the cylinder of a carding machine or steam engine.

verbs.description: lag (third-person singular simple present lags, present participle lagging, simple past and past participle lagged)

entries.meaning: To fail to keep up (the pace), to fall behind.
examples: Behind her farre away a Dwarfe did lag, / That lasie seemd in being ever last, / Or wearied with bearing of her bag / Of needments at his backe.

entries.meaning: To cover (for example, pipes) with felt strips or similar material (referring to a time lag effect in thermal transfer).
examples: Outside seems old enough: / Red brick, lagged pipes, and someone walking by it / Out to the car park, free.

entries.meaning: (computing, informal, video games) To respond slowly.
examples: My phone is starting to lag.

entries.meaning: (UK, slang, archaic) To transport as a punishment for crime.
examples: She lags us if we poach.

entries.meaning: (UK, slang, archaic) To arrest or apprehend.
(transitive) To cause to lag; to slacken.
examples: The weight would lagge thee that art wont to flye.
